Data Protection Policy(company level)
Purpose
This Data Protection Policy establishes Shuttle Plus�s commitment, governance and requirements for protecting personal data processed by the mobile app, backend systems and supporting services. It ensures compliance with Ethiopian data protection law, applicable sector rules and international best practice while safeguarding the privacy rights of customers, drivers, employees and partners.
Scope
This policy applies to all personal data processed by Shuttle Plus PLC and its subsidiaries, contractors and processors. It covers data collected, stored, transmitted or processed through mobile applications, APIs, databases, analytics systems, payment gateways, CRM, logs and manual records. It applies to all employees, contractors, vendors and third parties acting on Shuttle Plus�s behalf.

Definitions
Personal data: any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.
Processing: any operation performed on personal data including collection, storage, use, disclosure, erasure and transfer.
Controller: Shuttle Plus PLC when determining the purposes and means of processing.
Processor: any third party processing personal data on behalf of Shuttle Plus.
Data subject: the individual to whom personal data relates.
Principles
Shuttle Plus commits to process personal data in line with the following principles:
Lawful, fair and transparent processing.
Purpose limitation and data minimisation.
Accuracy and uptodate records.
Storage limitation and secure deletion.
Integrity and confidentiality through appropriate technical and organisational measures.
Accountability and demonstrable compliance.
Roles and Responsibilities
Board of Directors: ultimate accountability for data protection governance.
Data Protection Officer Privacy Lead: oversees compliance, DPIAs, regulatory liaison and incident reporting.
Data Owners Business Unit Leads: approve purpose, retention and access for their datasets.
Data Stewards Engineering Security Operations Support: implement and operate technical controls.
All staff: follow policies, report incidents and complete required training.
Lawful Basis and Transparency
All personal data processing must have a documented lawful basis (contract, consent, legal obligation, legitimate interest, or other lawful basis under applicable law). Clear privacy notices must be provided at point of collection describing purpose, lawful basis, retention period, recipients and data subject rights.

Data Inventory Classification and Retention
Maintain a live data inventory recording data elements, sources, flows, storage locations, processors, legal basis and retention.
Classify data sensitivity into tiers: Public Internal Confidential Highly Confidential. Apply stricter controls for higher tiers.
Implement retention schedules by data class and automate deletion or archival where possible. Record deletions in tamperevident logs.
Data Subject Rights
Shuttle Plus will enable and support the exercise of data subject rights including access rectification erasure restriction objection portability and rights related to automated decision making. Procedures must verify requester identity, log requests, meet statutory SLAs and record outcomes.
Consent and Preference Management
When relying on consent, consent must be freely given specific informed and revocable. Consent records must be stored with timestamps and contextual metadata. Preference management must allow customers to opt out of marketing and profiling where required.
Data Protection Impact Assessments
DPIAs are mandatory for highrisk processing such as GPS telemetry profiling KYC and large scale personal data analytics. DPIAs must identify risks mitigations residual risk and require privacy steering committee signoff before deployment.
Security Controls
Shuttle Plus will maintain appropriate technical and organisational measures including but not limited to:
Role based access control least privilege and periodic access reviews.
Multi factor authentication for administrative and remote access.
Encryption of personal data in transit and at rest with secure key management.
Secure development lifecycle code scanning and dependency management.
Parameterised queries and protections against injection attacks.
Network segmentation firewalls and WAF protection for public APIs.
Centralised logging SIEM and monitoring for anomalous access.
Encrypted backups secure retention and tested restore procedures.
PCI DSS controls for cardholder environment tokenisation and no CVV storage.
Third Party Processors
All processors must sign contracts requiring lawful processing technical and organisational measures breach notification and restrictions on onward transfers. Vendors must complete security and privacy assessments prior to onboarding and annually thereafter.
Cross Border Transfers
Transfers of personal data outside Ethiopia must have documented legal basis and safeguards such as regulator approvals contractual safeguards or equivalent measures. Data localisation requirements must be followed where law or contract requires.
Breach Notification and Incident Response
Shuttle Plus will maintain an incident response plan with roles escalation and forensic procedures. Reportable breaches will be notified to the regulator and affected data subjects within the statutory timeframe. All incidents will be logged investigated remediated and subject to postincident review.
Training and Awareness
All staff will receive data protection and security training at onboarding and annually; role based advanced training for engineers ops support and leadership. Regular phishing and tabletop exercises will be run.
Monitoring Audits and KPIs
The company will run periodic internal and external audits technical assessments and compliance reviews. Key metrics include percentage of data mapped DPIAs completed DSAR SLA compliance MTTD and MTTR for incidents and privileged access hygiene.
Enforcement and Sanctions
Violations of this policy may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination and may trigger contractual or legal remedies.
Policy Review
This policy will be reviewed annually and whenever legal regulatory or material business changes occur.
Technical Annex for Engineers and DBAs
Purpose
This annex translates policy requirements into actionable technical controls and configuration guidance for app developers SREs DBAs and security engineers.
Data Inventory and Tagging
Maintain a canonical schema registry and data catalogue (fields tables topics). Tag fields as PII Sensitive Payment KYC or Telemetry.
Implement schema validation in CI/CD to prevent unchecked schema drift.
Access Control and Authentication
Enforce RBAC with IAM groups mapped to least privilege roles.
Admin console and DB access require MFA and just in time privileged access via approved PAM solution.
Automate quarterly access reviews; orphan accounts disabled.
Encryption and Key Management
Use TLS 1.2+ for all transport. Enforce HSTS for web endpoints.
Encrypt at rest using AES 256 with cloud KMS or hardware module. Use envelope encryption for databaselevel keys.
Rotate keys quarterly or on compromise; log key usage with restricted access.
Database Hardening
Use parameterised queries or ORM prepared statements only. Prohibit string concatenation for queries.
Enable DB auditing to log SELECT INSERT UPDATE DELETE on PII tables; ship logs to immutable storage and SIEM.
Use row level encryption for highly confidential fields such as national ID or biometric tokens where performance permits.
Implement least privilege DB accounts: application read/write account limited to necessary schemas; no direct access to production from developer workstations.
Secrets and Configuration Management
Store secrets in a managed secrets store not in code or config repos. Inject secrets at runtime with short TTL tokens.
Enforce static analysis to flag accidental secrets in commits.
Application Security
Integrate SAST and DAST into CI/CD. Block builds with critical or high severity findings.
Enforce content security policy secure cookies HttpOnly SameSite and short session lifetimes with refresh tokens.
Rate limit endpoints and user actions to mitigate abuse and data harvesting.
Telemetry and Location Data
Minimise location precision where business does not require exact GPS. Use coarse geohashes for analytics.
Store raw highprecision GPS only when necessary with explicit lawful basis and additional encryption.
Implement retention automation to purge old telemetry per retention schedule.
Payment Card Handling
Use PCI validated payment processors. Tokenise card numbers. No storage of PAN unmasked or CVV. Segment card environment and apply enhanced logging and monitoring.
Logging and Monitoring
Log all administrative and schema changes and PII access events with user id timestamp and source IP.
Define SIEM alerts for anomalous read volumes unusual time access or crossregion access to PII.
Retain logs per forensic policy and protect against tampering with write once storage.
Backup and Restore
Encrypt backups and restrict restore operations to authorised personnel with multi party approval.
Test restores quarterly with verification that PII deletion processes are effective in restored copies.

Vendor Integrations
Use narrow scoped API keys per vendor with IP whitelisting and mutual TLS where feasible.
Require vendors to attest to minimum encryption and access controls and permit security assessments.
Data Subject Requests Implementation
Expose authenticated API endpoints for subject requests with rate limits and verification checks.
Implement job queue for DSAR processing produce audit trail of actions taken and ensure deletions cascade to backups and caches within policy constraints.
CI/CD and Change Control
Schema or data flow changes must submit a privacy/security impact checklist. Block deploys without required approvals for high risk changes.
Deploy feature flags to allow rapid rollback of features that cause privacy regressions.
Incident Playbook Highlights
Immediate containment isolate systems rotate keys disable compromised accounts and preserve volatile evidence.
Trigger notification workflow DPO Legal Communications Forensics and escalate to regulator if threshold met.
Produce post incident report with root cause remediation timeline and code or config fixes.
Next Steps
Approve this policy and annex for legal review and Board sign off.
Appoint DPO and form the Privacy Steering Committee.
Begin implementing the technical controls in the annex starting with RBAC MFA encryption and DSAR workflows.

Design goals and trade-offs (pick these first)
Consistency vs availability: choose strong consistency for financial/booking flows; choose eventual for telemetry and bulk ingest.
Latency vs durability: local writes (edge) reduce latency but need robust sync/merge strategies.
Operational complexity vs vendor lock-in: managed cloud services reduce ops but increase coupling; distributed DBs add ops burden.
Cost predictability vs elasticity: provisioned clusters cost more but are predictable; serverless scales but can spike costs.

Recommended architectures by use-case
Booking, payments, critical state (Shuttle reservations)
Primary: Managed PostgreSQL (multi-AZ) or CockroachDB for geo resilience and strong consistency.
Redundancy: Synchronous or semi-synchronous replicas within region; async cross-region replicas for DR.
Backup: Automated PITR (point-in-time recovery) + daily snapshots stored in a separate region.
Telemetry and trip logs (high-write ingest)
Primary: Cassandra/Scylla or DynamoDB for high write throughput and multi-DC replication.
Redundancy: Multi-AZ with replication factor 3; tombstone and compaction tuning.
Archival: Batch export to cold storage (S3/Blob) for compliance and analytics.
Mobile/edge sync (drivers, kiosks)
Primary: SQLite or Realm/Couchbase Mobile on device + conflict-aware sync to cloud (Sync Gateway / Realm Sync).
Redundancy: Local-first UX; server reconciler and authoritative conflict resolution rules.
Offline policy: allow local bookings with provisional IDs, reconcile on sync.
Caching and ephemeral state
Primary: Redis Cluster with AOF + RDB persistence and Sentinel for failover.
Use for session data, rate limiting, queue offsets.
Event-driven orchestration and audit
Primary: Kafka or managed equivalent (MSK/Event Hubs) for durable event log and replayable workflows.
Redundancy: Replication across AZs/regions, retention and consumer groups for reprocessing.

Redundancy patterns and how to implement them
Multi-AZ replication: ensures single data-center failure tolerance; combine with automated failover and health probes.
Multi-region replication: protects against region-level outages; choose async replication for cross-region to avoid latency impact.
Synchronous vs asynchronous replication: use sync inside region for zero data loss; use async cross-region to limit write latency.
Quorum and replication factor: tune RF >= 3 for Cassandra; configure write/read quorums to balance durability vs availability.
Read replicas and promotion: use read replicas for scale and a safe promotion path (avoid split-brain with fencing / leader leases).
Backup + PITR: schedule frequent incremental snapshots, weekly fulls, and test restores quarterly.
Blue/Green and failover playbooks: automate DNS TTL reductions, traffic shifting, and runbooked DB promotion steps.

Cloud planning checklist (operational steps)
Inventory data types and SLOs: RTO/RPO for each dataset (bookings, telemetry, profiles).
Choose primary and secondary regions based on latency and regulatory requirements.
Select DB technology per dataset (map from section above).
Define replication topology, backup cadence, retention, and encryption-at-rest + in-transit.
Plan capacity: baseline throughput + headroom for 2x peak with autoscaling policies.
Observability: metrics (lag, replication health, commit latency), alerts, and synthetic checks for failover.
Disaster Recovery drills: scheduled failover tests, data-restore dry runs, and SLA reviews.
Cost control: reserved instances or committed use where applicable, and budget alerts for egress/IO spikes.
Security/compliance: RBAC, IAM, network isolation (VPC/NSG), DB auditing, and key management.
Define offline sync and reconciliation strategy for edge devices (idempotency, merge rules, loss handling).

Migration and DR playbook (one-page summary)
Pre-migration: freeze window, take full snapshot, validate schema compatibility, communicate stakeholders.
Cutover: dual-writes for a trial window; monitor divergence; promote new system once divergence < threshold.
Rollback: keep old system writable until post-cutover validation; maintain rollback snapshot.
DR test: annually simulate region loss; execute failover to secondary region and validate end-to-end app flows within RTO.
Post-incident: run root-cause analysis, update runbooks, and cadence for follow-up fixes.

Operational recommendations tailored for Shuttle Plus
Critical booking state: Managed PostgreSQL (multi-AZ) with read-replicas and PITR; implement a short synchronous replica in-country for low-latency bookings and an async cross-region replica for DR.
Driver/mobile offline flows: SQLite or Realm on-device with deterministic conflict resolution and server-side reconciliation service; grant provisional booking IDs and a reconciliation queue for duplicates.
Telemetry: Use a time-series optimized store or DynamoDB/Cassandra with batching at the edge; ship compressed batches when connectivity resumes.
Event sourcing: Append key state changes (booking created, confirmed, boarded) to Kafka for replay, audits, and rebuilding projections after restores.
Budget: start with managed services to reduce ops overhead; when scale justifies, evaluate CockroachDB or Scylla to reduce cross-region costs.

Use the roles and cadence already in your operating model (Finance Lead, Ops Lead, Procurement Lead, Fleet Manager, PM, GC/CCO for legal/insurance items).

  2602→Core categories to track (mandatory tags)

  2911→Driver behavior & safety (harsh braking, speeding) � Samsara, Motive, and Verizon Connect have mature driver scoring and dashcam integrations.
  2912→Offline / low-connectivity support � Traccar (self-hosted) and Odoo can be tuned for intermittent connectivity; many enterprise cloud platforms struggle without reliable mobile networks.

2. Core conduct standards (must-follow)
Appearance: Clean uniform, badge visible, shoes polished, hair/tidiness neat.
Punctuality: Be at the vehicle 10 minutes before shift start; notify ops if >15 minutes late.

Privacy & dignity: Do not discuss passenger details aloud; handle personal items respectfully.
Safety first: Follow vehicle checks, seatbelt policy, and luggage loading protocols every trip.
No escalation: De-escalate calmly; if unresolved, hand to shift lead and open an incident report.

3. Language scripts � Short, actionable phrases

Greeting (English): �Hello, Shuttle Plus � is this [name]? I�ll help with your luggage.�

Confirm booking (English): �May I see your booking or name for verification?�
Tagging luggage (Amharic): �Amesegenallo � tag yibelachu, beka yenor?�

Offer add-ons (Amharic): �Betam wadagim � wede snack/water/premium seeting interest new?�
Offer add-ons (English): �Would you like a snack, water, or priority boarding today?�
Handling delays/issues (Amharic): �Yiqirta � I�ll inform dispatch and we�ll resolve it quickly.�

Closing (Amharic): �Amaseginalesh � shiftoch genzeb yemiwedek.�

Use the Amharic line first, then repeat in English if passenger appears international or requests English.


4. Tool interaction phrases (app/POS/incident logging)
When selling add-on (spoken): �I�ll add this to your booking now � it�s ETB [X].�
When confirming POS success: �Payment received; here�s your receipt.�
If POS fails: �Payment didn�t go through � I�ll try again or we can use another method.�
When creating an incident: �I�ll log this now and the ops team will update you within [SLA].�

5. Role-play scenarios (3 short exercises)

Expense tracking plan for Shuttle Plus
A practical, operational expense tracking plan tailored for a transport/logistics platform. Focus: accurate cost capture, timely reporting, control, and decision-ready dashboards. Use the roles and cadence already in your operating model (Finance Lead, Ops Lead, Procurement Lead, Fleet Manager, PM, GC/CCO for legal/insurance items).
Goals and principles
Goals: capture all operational costs accurately; allocate costs by route, vehicle, city zone and product line; detect overruns early; support pricing, forecasting and insurer/audit evidence.
Principles: single source of truth for transactions; timely (weekly) reconciliation; role-based approvals; granular tagging (trip, vehicle, supplier, cost type); immutable evidence for audits.
Core categories to track (mandatory tags)
Fleet: fuel, maintenance, tires, spare parts, depreciation, lease payments, parking, tolls.
People: driver wages, benefits, training, recruitment, incentives.
Platform & Tech: hosting, maps/routing fees, SMS/calls, payments fees, software subscriptions, CLM/LMS line items.
Operations: dispatch costs, call centre, rider refunds, driver incentives, cleaning.
Insurance & Legal: motor/public liability premiums, D&O, cyber, claims, retainer fees.
Procurement & Supplies: uniforms, PPE, office supplies, charging/energy for EVs.
Regulatory & Licensing: permits, inspections, fines and renewals.
Marketing & Commercial: promos, corporate account discounts, partnerships.
Contingency & Claims: incident payouts, customer remediation, arbitration/legal settlements.
Always tag each expense with: date, invoice number, vendor, GL code, project/trip ID (if applicable), vehicle ID, zone/city, and approval owner.
Tools and data flows
Use a cloud accounting system (e.g., Xero, QuickBooks) integrated with: 
Expense capture app for drivers and staff (mobile receipts, OCR).
Fleet management telematics (automatically log fuel, vehicle km, service events).
Payments and gateway feeds (auto ingest transactions and fees).
CLM/contract repo for periodic vendor payments and insurance schedules.
Master data sources: vehicle register, supplier master, driver roster, route catalogue. Sync nightly to avoid stale tags.
Expense capture process (day-to-day)
Capture: vendor invoices, driver claims, card transactions, and payment batches enter system within 3 business days. Mobile receipts must be uploaded within 24 hours.
Auto-tagging: apply vendor ? category rules; telematics feed auto-attach vehicle ID and km to fuel/maintenance lines.
Manual review: Finance reviewer inspects exceptions and untagged items daily.
Approval: owner-level approval for expenses above thresholds (e.g., >ETB X) before payment. Approvals routed through accounting tool.
Reconciliation: weekly bank and card reconciliation; match payments to invoices and trips.
Archive: store PDF scans and contracts with immutable timestamps; link to expense line.
Allocation and cost models
Direct allocation: tie fuel, maintenance, and driver wages to vehicle and trip IDs for per-trip costing.
Shared costs allocation: split platform, regional office rent, and shared tools by driver-hours, trips, or revenue share per zone. Document allocation keys in accounting policy.
Depreciation: apply straight-line vehicle depreciation with salvage values recorded in fixed assets.
Cost per km and cost per trip: compute both as primary operational metrics.

Approval thresholds and controls
Low-value (? ETB X): team lead approval (Ops/Procurement).
Medium-value (ETB X�Y): Department Head + Finance review.
High-value (> ETB Y): CFO/CEO sign-off plus GC for legal/insurance exposures.
Singleuse or unusual vendors require vendor onboarding (KYB proof, insurance certificate) before payment.

Reporting cadence and deliverables
Daily (ops dashboard): cash in/out summary, top 10 exceptions, fuel burn / km, live contingency drawdowns.
Weekly (ops finance sync): P&L flash vs budget by major category; top 5 variances with root causes; outstanding invoices >30 days; driver payout reconciliation.
Monthly (management pack): month P&L, cash flow, burn vs plan, cost per km/trip by zone, vendor performance, insurance claim activity, open PO and contract obligations.
Quarterly (board / Legal Risk Committee): deeper variance analysis, audit sampling results, insurance adequacy review, contingency adequacy, and action plan.
Adhoc: incident cost report within 72 hours of material event (accident, major outage).
KPIs and thresholds to monitor
Cost per km (all-in) and cost per active km (operational).
Cost per trip and contribution margin per trip.
Fuel cost variance and average fuel efficiency (L/100km).
Maintenance cost per vehicle per month; % of fleet out-of-service days.
Driver labour cost as % of revenue.
Days payable outstanding (DPO) and days sales outstanding (DSO) for corporate customers.
Invoice exception rate and late payment frequency.
Contingency reserve vs 90day liquidation needs (target: 1�3 months of legal/compliance burn).
Trigger alerts: set automated alerts for KPI breaches (e.g., cost per km > plan +10%; fleet downtime > threshold; single vendor spend > 20% monthly).
Audit, reconciliation and verification
Weekly sample testing by Finance: select 20 expense lines, verify invoice, GL coding, approval, and evidence.
Monthly supplier statement reconciliation for top 20 vendors.
Quarterly external spot-check by internal audit or third party for high-value categories (insurance reconciliations, claims reserve accuracy).
Maintain immutable evidence pack for auditors: contracts, insurance certificates, signed approvals, incident remediation invoices.

Integration with pricing and forecasting
Feed nightly cost-per-km/trip metrics into pricing model. Use rolling 30/90-day windows for fuel, maintenance and wage cost inputs.
Scenario stress tests for fuel spikes and permit-related stoppages; include tax/regulatory cost sensitivity in 12-month forecasts.
Monthly review of pricing tiers if cost-per-trip drifts outside tolerance band.

Roles and RACI (summary)
Finance Lead: owns accounting system, reconciliations, monthly pack, approvals.
Ops Lead / Fleet Manager: inputs telemetry and vehicle events, raises maintenance POs, approves operational exceptions.
Procurement Lead: vendor onboarding, KYB/KYC, supplier contracts, supply-side disputes.
Project Manager: runs weekly remediation of exceptions and ensures evidence capture.
Legal / GC: review contracts, claims, insurance coverage and approvals for high-risk spend.
CEO/CFO: approve high-value contingency draws and changes to allocation policy.

Quick-start checklist (first 30 days)
Set up chart of accounts with categories above and mandatory tags.
Integrate telematics, payments, and expense capture apps to accounting system.
Create vendor master and require KYB/insurance documents for top 50 suppliers.
Launch mobile receipt policy and 24-hour upload rule.
Configure weekly reports and automated KPI alerts.
Run first-week reconciliation and present one-page cost heatmap to leadership.

Fleet management software � shortlist and recommendation (free-first)
Below are 12 fleet management software options (free or low-cost prioritized), summarize their selling points, where they beat the market, limitations for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia, and a clear recommendation with an implementation path.

Shortlist (12 products; free / open-source options first)
Traccar (open-source, free)
OpenGTS / OpenFleet (open-source, free)
Odoo Fleet (community edition � free core)
FleetOps / FleetSharp (low-cost options / local vendors vary)
GPSWOX (freemium)
Fleetio (paid; free trial)
Samsara (paid; market leader for telematics)
Verizon Connect (paid; enterprise)
Teletrac Navman (paid; enterprise)
KeepTruckin / Motive (paid; strong dashcam/ELD integration)
GpsGate (hosted or self-hosted; flexible pricing)
CalAmp / Mix Telematics (paid; regional presence)

Quick one-line positioning
Traccar: Best no-cost GPS tracking and self-hosting control.
OpenGTS: Classic open-source telematics platform for full customization.
Odoo Fleet: Lightweight fleet module as part of a wider ERP (free community edition).
GPSWOX: Freemium option with quick setup and mobile apps.
Fleetio: Excellent fleet lifecycle, maintenance, and procurement workflows.
Samsara: Full-stack telematics + dashcams + analytics at scale.
Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp: Enterprise-grade reliability, compliance, and support.
KeepTruckin/Motive: Strong on compliance, driver safety, and dashcams.
GpsGate: Flexible self-hosted or cloud; good for integrators.
FleetOps/FleetSharp: Regional/SMB-focused solutions with local support.

Feature comparison (what matters to Shuttle Plus)
GPS tracking & live location � essential for airport ETAs. Traccar, GpsGate, Samsara, and Fleetio provide strong solutions (Traccar/GpsGate allow self-hosting).
Maintenance & TCO workflows � Fleetio and Odoo Fleet excel at maintenance scheduling, parts, and procurement.
Driver behavior & safety (harsh braking, speeding) � Samsara, Motive, and Verizon Connect have mature driver scoring and dashcam integrations.
Offline / low-connectivity support � Traccar (self-hosted) and Odoo can be tuned for intermittent connectivity; many enterprise cloud platforms struggle without reliable mobile networks.
Integration & APIs � GpsGate, Traccar, Fleetio, and Samsara offer robust APIs for booking apps and dispatch systems.
Cost & deployment flexibility � Open-source (Traccar, OpenGTS) and Odoo Community provide lowest licensing cost; hosted enterprise solutions carry high recurring fees.
Local payments, SMS/WhatsApp, mobile-money events � Most open platforms allow custom integrations; SaaS vendors may require paid connectors.
Dashcam and video telematics � Samsara, Motive, and CalAmp are leaders; costly but valuable for claims and safety.
Multi-tenant / partner fleet governance � GpsGate and some enterprise platforms support multi-tenant accounts for franchise/partner oversight.

Where each option beats the market (concise)
Traccar � unbeatable price (free), self-hosting, and support for many GPS devices; best for bootstrapped operations that want full data control.
OpenGTS � mature open stack for custom telematics; good for integrations but requires heavy dev.
Odoo Fleet � best if you already plan to use Odoo ERP for HR, accounting and operations; low-cost integration across modules.
Fleetio � market-leading maintenance workflows, audits, inspections, and inventory tracking.
GpsGate � flexible deployment; strong multi-tenant and reseller features for partner fleets.
Samsara � best-in-class telematics + video + analytics; premium pricing but reduces claims and improves safety rapidly.
Motive / KeepTruckin � best where driver compliance and video evidence are primary concerns.
Verizon Connect / Teletrac / CalAmp � strong enterprise SLAs, regional support, and compliance for large-scale ops.

Best fit for Shuttle Plus (recommended stack and why)
Recommendation: Start with a hybrid stack combining Traccar (self-hosted) or GpsGate (self-hosted/cloud) for real-time tracking + Odoo Community for fleet & maintenance workflows, then selectively add paid telematics/dashcam services (Samsara or Motive) for specific high-value vehicles.
Why this combination works for Shuttle Plus in Ethiopia:
Cost-sensitive: Traccar + Odoo Community has minimal licensing cost and avoids heavy recurring SaaS fees.
Control & data sovereignty: Self-hosting keeps location and passenger-related telemetry under company control and avoids costly international bandwidth/SaaS contracts.
Offline resilience: Open platforms can be configured for intermittent mobile connectivity and local SMS/WhatsApp integration for ETAs.
Modular scale: Start small (GPS tracking + inspections) and add premium telematics/dashcams for core corporate or high-liability routes only.
Integration with existing operations: Odoo gives a lightweight route into HR, maintenance, asset management, and invoicing without building an entire ERP from scratch.
Partner governance: GpsGate or Traccar + custom dashboards allow multi-tenant views to audit partner/franchise fleets.

Implementation plan (practical, phased)
Phase 0 � Decisions and procurement (Week 0�2)
Choose primary tracking platform (Traccar or GpsGate) and confirm hosting (on-prem server in Addis or low-cost cloud region).
Choose Odoo Community for fleet/maintenance or evaluate Fleetio paid plan if budget allows.
Phase 1 � Pilot (Week 2�8)
Equip 10�15 core vehicles with reliable GPS trackers (Teltonika, Queclink, Meitrack are common and supported).
Deploy Traccar (self-host) and connect devices; configure geofences for Bole Airport, hotels, and hubs.
Set up Odoo Fleet: vehicle records, maintenance schedules, DVIR templates, and driver profiles.
Integrate basic webhook/API between booking app and Traccar for live ETAs and SMS/WhatsApp alerts.
Phase 2 � Expand & add governance (Week 8�16)
Add analytics dashboards: utilization, on-time pickup rate, idle time, and geofence breaches.
Onboard partner fleets with multi-tenant views; enforce vehicle acceptance checklist via Odoo inspections.
Run 90-day QA and maintenance KPI review; adjust trackers and workflows.
Phase 3 � Add premium telematics where needed (Quarter 2�4)
For corporate contracts, add Samsara or Motive devices/dashcams on assigned vehicles; use their safety analytics for incentive programs.
Add automated incident evidence flow: dashcam clips attached to incident tickets in Odoo.

Costs and device notes (practical guidance)
GPS trackers: basic Teltonika/Queclink units (LTE/GPS) cost ~USD 30�90 per device; choose models with battery backup.
Hosting: a small cloud instance for Traccar can run ~USD 10�40/month; on-prem adds hardware CAPEX but reduces foreign recurring costs.
Odoo Community: free for software; expect implementation time and modest hosting costs; paid Odoo apps or consultants add cost.
Samsara/Motive: device + subscription per vehicle can be costly (USD tens/month); reserve for high-value assets.

Risks and mitigations
Device theft / tampering � use tamper alerts, VIN registration, and immobilizer integration where possible.
Mobile connectivity gaps � configure trackers to store data offline and upload when connected; use SMS-based fallback for ETA notifications.
Local support � prioritize vendors with local partners or reliable remote setup guides; plan for spare device inventory.
Data privacy / regulatory � store audit logs, anonymize PII when not needed, and document local compliance for airport/transport regulators.


Fleet strategy overview
Shuttle Plus manages fleet across small, large, and seasonal scenarios with a single unified playbook that emphasizes modular capacity, cost predictability, safety, and rapid scalability. The playbook has three pillars: Rightsizing (match capacity to demand), Resilience (maintenance, backups, supplier diversity), and Operational agility (datadriven dispatch, dynamic rostering, rapid onboarding/offboarding of vehicles and drivers).
1. Small fleet scenario (up to ~25 vehicles)
Organizational model
Centralized ops: Fleet Manager + combined roles (dispatcher, maintenance lead, admin).
Multiskilling: Drivers perform basic checks; one oncall technician for repairs.
Procurement & composition
Mix of 12�15 seat minibuses and 4�8 seat sedans for flexibility.
Prefer owned vehicles for reliability; hold 1�2 leased backups.
Maintenance & reliability
Preventive schedule: weekly checks by drivers, monthly technician inspection, 3,000�5,000 km minor service cadence.
Spare pool: 1 dedicated spare vehicle; rotate to avoid age clustering.
Operations
Central dispatch with manual surge rules; simple routing templates (airport, hotel loops).
Fixed rosters with floaters to cover sick leave and peak windows.
Cost controls
Tight fuel tracking, consolidated supplier invoicing, simple telematics for fuel and idling metrics.
KPI targets
Availability ? 92%; ontime pickup ? 90%; preventive compliance 100%.
2. Large fleet scenario (25�200+ vehicles)
Organizational model
Distributed hubs: multiple dispatch hubs; Hub Managers, Fleet Supervisors, Maintenance Team, Regional Planner.
Dedicated teams: procurement, parts inventory, training, QA.
Procurement & composition
Diversified mix: minibuses, 12�18 seat shuttles, sedans, and a small number of larger coaches for bulk runs.
Blend of ownership and longterm leases to optimize capex vs opex.
Maintenance & lifecycle
Tiered maintenance program: daily driver checks, weekly shop checks, mileage/time based services, scheduled midlife refurb.
Inhouse workshop for routine work; external authorized partners for heavy repairs. Central parts inventory with reorder automation.
Operations & capacity management
Advanced dispatch platform with dynamic routing, load balancing across hubs, and automated peak rules.

  3412→Purpose
  3413→Define the data model, capture flows, privacy controls, and operational notes to reliably address repeat customers by name across channels while preserving security, accuracy, and consent.
  3414→
  3415→1. Data model and required fields
  3416→CustomerID (unique, system generated) � primary key.
  3417→FirstName � canonical preferred given name.
  3418→LastName � family name.
  3419→DisplayName � what to show in-app/voice (e.g., �Abel�, �Ms. Bekele�).
  3420→NameVariants � commaseparated alternates and common misspellings; use for fuzzy matching.
  3421→PreferredLanguage � ISO code; influences greeting phrasing.
  3422→PreferredHonorific � optional (Mr/Ms/Dr/etc.) for formal channels.
  3423→ContactPrimary � phone number (E.164) or primary identifier.
  3424→ContactSecondary � email or alternate phone.
  3425→Verified � boolean indicating identity verification status.
  3426→ConsentForPersonalization � boolean; explicit optin for being addressed by name.
  3427→LastSeen � timestamp of last ride/checkin.
  3428→UsageCount � integer count of completed transactions.
  3429→CustomerTier � e.g., Frequent, VIP, New (optional).
  3430→Notes � free text for operational flags (e.g., �prefers text only�).
  3431→Source � origin of record (app, kiosk, phone, partner).
  3432→CreatedAt / UpdatedAt � timestamps for audit.
  3433→Sample singleline CSV header: CustomerID,FirstName,LastName,DisplayName,NameVariants,PreferredLanguage,PreferredHonorific,ContactPrimary,ContactSecondary,Verified,ConsentForPersonalization,LastSeen,UsageCount,CustomerTier,Notes,Source,CreatedAt,UpdatedAt
  3434→
  3435→

  3437→2. Capture flows and identity verification
  3438→Inapp signup: collect FirstName, DisplayName, ContactPrimary, PreferredLanguage, and explicit toggle for personalization consent. Require phone verification (OTP) before marking Verified = true.
  3439→Kiosk/phone intake: collect same fields and confirm spelling aloud; if customer declines personalization, set ConsentForPersonalization = false. If agent creates record, set Source = kiosk/phone and note agent ID in Notes.
  3440→Backfill from bookings: merge records using deterministic keys (phone, email) and fuzzy match on NameVariants; flag merges for review.
  3441→Verification policy: treat Verified = true only after OTP or matched government ID in higherrisk refunds/claims.
  3442→
  3443→3. Personalization rules and safe addressing
  3444→Consent check: address customers by name only if ConsentForPersonalization = true. If false, use neutral phrasing (e.g., �Guest� or booking reference).
  3445→Channel tailoring: 
  3446→App push/inapp: use DisplayName.
  3447→SMS: use FirstName if ConsentForPersonalization is true and message length permits.
  3448→Phone/Kiosk/Agent scripts: use PreferredHonorific + LastName for formal interactions when Requested or for older customers; otherwise use DisplayName.
  3449→Voice assistants: prefer DisplayName and shorter names for natural speech.
  3450→Fallbacks: if DisplayName missing but FirstName exists, use FirstName; if no name and consent false, use �Valued customer� + BookingID.
  3451→Frequency throttle: avoid overpersonalization in mass messages�limit name usage to highrelevance messages (booking confirmations, incident updates).
  3452→Respect cultural naming: respect ordering (family vs given) and diacritics stored in Unicode; show transliterations only if requested.
  3453→Personalization example rules (pseudocode):
  3454→If ConsentForPersonalization == true and UsageCount >= 2 then Greeting = �Hi {DisplayName},� else Greeting = �Hello,�.
  3455→
  3456→
  3457→4. Matching, duplicates, and name variants
  3458→Primary match keys: ContactPrimary, ContactSecondary.
  3459→Secondary fuzzy matching: normalized name comparison (strip diacritics, common abbreviations, whitespace), and compare with NameVariants; require at least one contact match or manual review to merge.
  3460→Merge policy: when merging, preserve original records in an audit log, consolidate NameVariants, sum UsageCount, set Verified = true if either record verified, and notify customer by secure channel of consolidation.
  3461→Conflict resolution: when conflicting ConsentForPersonalization values exist, preserve the more privacyprotective choice (i.e., false) and flag for agent followup.
  3462→
  3463→5. Privacy, retention, and optout
  3464→Explicit consent: store ConsentForPersonalization and timestamp of consent. Use consent for name addressing only.
  3465→Optout workflow: immediate effect � update ConsentForPersonalization = false across systems; purge DisplayName from outgoing templates and use neutral identifiers. Log optout event.
  3466→Data minimization: keep only fields required for personalization and service delivery. Remove or archive obsolete contacts after retention period.
  3467→Retention rules: keep active frequent user records while UsageCount > 0 and LastSeen within 24 months; archive after 24 months of inactivity and delete after companypolicy or legal retention period.
  3468→Access control and encryption: restrict read/write to authorized roles; encrypt contact fields at rest; mask names in logs where not required.
  3469→Audit trail: log all read/write actions on customer records with staff ID, reason, and timestamp.
  3470→
  3471→6. Implementation checklist and quick tasks
  3472→Schema creation in DB and CSV import template using header above.
  3473→Implement capture flows: app form with consent toggle + OTP; agent intake form with explicit consent question.
  3474→Build matching/merge job: deterministic merges by contact, weekly fuzzy match batch with manual review queue.
  3475→Personalization API: endpoint that returns Greeting text given CustomerID, channel, and context; enforce consent/usage rules serverside.
  3476→Optout API and UI: oneclick optout in app and agent dashboard; propagate immediately to messaging platform.
  3477→Logging and monitoring: dashboards for UsageCount, consent rates, merge conflicts, and optout events.
  3478→Training: agent scripts for asking name and consent, and escalation flow for disputes.
  3479→Pilot: run a 4week pilot with highvolume users, monitor errors, and refine NameVariants logic.

  3482→Agent script to ask permission: �May I address you by your name in messages and when we call to improve your experience? We will only use it with your permission.� If yes, record ConsentForPersonalization = true and preferred DisplayName.

90day fleet scaling playbook � Addis Ababa launch
Summary
Goal: field a reliable, auditable, and scalable shuttle operation in Addis Ababa that meets airport transfer demand and scales through early growth and seasonality.
Timeframe: 90 days (Weeks 0�13).
Primary output: phased vehicle counts, staffing templates, procurement & maintenance actions, operational playbooks, and daily/weekly KPIs.

Phase structure (high level)
Phase 0 � Ready (Days 0�7): approvals, contracts, core hires, initial vehicles.
Phase 1 � Launch (Days 8�30): soft launch at priority sites; validate ops, refine SOPs, certify staff.
Phase 2 � Scale (Days 31�60): add vehicles, expand hubs, formalize partner agreements.
Phase 3 � Stabilize & Optimize (Days 61�90): reach target utilization, refine forecasting, finalize seasonal playbook.

Target vehicle counts (recommended baseline and scale triggers)
Baseline (Day 0�7) � Minimal viable fleet 
6 x 1215 seat minibuses (airport/core shuttle)
3 x 45 seat sedans (VIP/corporate/lastmile)
1 x spare vehicle (any type) for immediate swap
Total baseline = 10 vehicles
Launch target (Day 8�30) � Reliable coverage for primary airport and hotel clusters 
Add 4 minibuses + 2 sedans
Total = 16 vehicles
Scale target (Day 31�60) � Support growing bookings, add CBD pilot and bus terminal 
Add 6 minibuses + 3 sedans (or 1 coach for group runs) via lease or partner ops
Total = 25 vehicles
High demand / seasonal readiness (Day 61�90) � 20�30% overflow capacity via partners 
Activate 5�8 leased or partner vehicles (minibuses) staged at demand nodes
Operational control total = 30+ vehicles (mix of owned + leased + partner)
Scale triggers (automatic actions)
+20% weekoverweek bookings for 2 consecutive weeks ? deploy 4 leased minibuses and recruit 6 drivers.
Average pickup wait >12 minutes for 3 consecutive days ? add 2 vehicles to affected hub or reallocate floaters.

Staffing templates (roles, counts, and rotas)
Baseline staffing (10 vehicles)
Fleet Manager (1) � overall accountability (day shift).
Dispatchers (2) � 24/7 coverage via shift split; primary dispatcher + night floater.
Drivers (14) � 1.4 drivers per vehicle to cover shifts, rest, and sick leave.
Technicians / mechanic (1 fulltime) + oncall partner.
Kiosk / Customer attendants (4) � split across airport & hotel; staffed peak windows.
Onboarding/Account Success (1 parttime) for early corporate signups.
Supervisor (Operations) (1) � gapcover and QA.
Launch staffing (16 vehicles)
Add 6 drivers (total 20 drivers).
Add 1 dispatcher (total 3).
Add 1 technician or upgrade to 1.5 FTE via partner.
Add 2 kiosk attendants (total 6).
Add 1 rostered field supervisor per major site (airport).
Scale staffing (25 vehicles)
Fleet Manager (1) + Assistant Fleet Supervisor (1).
Dispatch hub staff: 1 Hub Manager + 4 dispatchers (rotate 24/7).
Drivers: 1.6 drivers per vehicle ? ~40 drivers.
Maintenance: 2 technicians + mobile roadside tech (contract).
Kiosk attendants: 8�10 across sites.
Training & QA lead (1) to maintain OSAT throughput.
Sample shift model (for drivers and dispatchers)
Driver shifts: 10�12 hour shift; rotate 5 days on / 2 off; provide peak overlap windows (05:00�11:00 and 16:00�22:00).
Dispatcher shifts: three 8hour shifts to ensure continuous monitoring; oncall supervisor overnight.
Hiring and onboarding cadence
Week 0�2: hire Fleet Manager, 40% of drivers (for baseline + launch), 1 dispatcher, 1 technician, core attendants.
Week 3�6: hire remaining drivers to meet launch target; begin accelerated seasonal roster recruiting.
Week 7�13: recruit for scale target and maintain standby pool of precertified drivers.
Driver vetting and certification
Minimum: valid driving license, background check, medical clearance, vehicle safety OSAT (practical), customer service micromodule.
Certification: Level 1 Verified Operator required before solo duty.

Procurement and sourcing plan
Vehicle procurement mix

Frequent User Database Setup
Purpose
Define the data model, capture flows, privacy controls, and operational notes to reliably address repeat customers by name across channels while preserving security, accuracy, and consent.

1. Data model and required fields
CustomerID (unique, system generated) � primary key.
FirstName � canonical preferred given name.
LastName � family name.
DisplayName � what to show in-app/voice (e.g., �Abel�, �Ms. Bekele�).
NameVariants � commaseparated alternates and common misspellings; use for fuzzy matching.
PreferredLanguage � ISO code; influences greeting phrasing.
PreferredHonorific � optional (Mr/Ms/Dr/etc.) for formal channels.
ContactPrimary � phone number (E.164) or primary identifier.
ContactSecondary � email or alternate phone.
Verified � boolean indicating identity verification status.
ConsentForPersonalization � boolean; explicit optin for being addressed by name.
LastSeen � timestamp of last ride/checkin.
UsageCount � integer count of completed transactions.
CustomerTier � e.g., Frequent, VIP, New (optional).
Notes � free text for operational flags (e.g., �prefers text only�).
Source � origin of record (app, kiosk, phone, partner).
CreatedAt / UpdatedAt � timestamps for audit.
Sample singleline CSV header: CustomerID,FirstName,LastName,DisplayName,NameVariants,PreferredLanguage,PreferredHonorific,ContactPrimary,ContactSecondary,Verified,ConsentForPersonalization,LastSeen,UsageCount,CustomerTier,Notes,Source,CreatedAt,UpdatedAt



2. Capture flows and identity verification
Inapp signup: collect FirstName, DisplayName, ContactPrimary, PreferredLanguage, and explicit toggle for personalization consent. Require phone verification (OTP) before marking Verified = true.
Kiosk/phone intake: collect same fields and confirm spelling aloud; if customer declines personalization, set ConsentForPersonalization = false. If agent creates record, set Source = kiosk/phone and note agent ID in Notes.
Backfill from bookings: merge records using deterministic keys (phone, email) and fuzzy match on NameVariants; flag merges for review.
Verification policy: treat Verified = true only after OTP or matched government ID in higherrisk refunds/claims.

3. Personalization rules and safe addressing
Consent check: address customers by name only if ConsentForPersonalization = true. If false, use neutral phrasing (e.g., �Guest� or booking reference).
Channel tailoring: 
App push/inapp: use DisplayName.
SMS: use FirstName if ConsentForPersonalization is true and message length permits.
Phone/Kiosk/Agent scripts: use PreferredHonorific + LastName for formal interactions when Requested or for older customers; otherwise use DisplayName.
Voice assistants: prefer DisplayName and shorter names for natural speech.
Fallbacks: if DisplayName missing but FirstName exists, use FirstName; if no name and consent false, use �Valued customer� + BookingID.
Frequency throttle: avoid overpersonalization in mass messages�limit name usage to highrelevance messages (booking confirmations, incident updates).
Respect cultural naming: respect ordering (family vs given) and diacritics stored in Unicode; show transliterations only if requested.
Personalization example rules (pseudocode):
If ConsentForPersonalization == true and UsageCount >= 2 then Greeting = �Hi {DisplayName},� else Greeting = �Hello,�.


4. Matching, duplicates, and name variants
Primary match keys: ContactPrimary, ContactSecondary.
Secondary fuzzy matching: normalized name comparison (strip diacritics, common abbreviations, whitespace), and compare with NameVariants; require at least one contact match or manual review to merge.
Merge policy: when merging, preserve original records in an audit log, consolidate NameVariants, sum UsageCount, set Verified = true if either record verified, and notify customer by secure channel of consolidation.
Conflict resolution: when conflicting ConsentForPersonalization values exist, preserve the more privacyprotective choice (i.e., false) and flag for agent followup.

5. Privacy, retention, and optout
Explicit consent: store ConsentForPersonalization and timestamp of consent. Use consent for name addressing only.
Optout workflow: immediate effect � update ConsentForPersonalization = false across systems; purge DisplayName from outgoing templates and use neutral identifiers. Log optout event.
Data minimization: keep only fields required for personalization and service delivery. Remove or archive obsolete contacts after retention period.
Retention rules: keep active frequent user records while UsageCount > 0 and LastSeen within 24 months; archive after 24 months of inactivity and delete after companypolicy or legal retention period.
Access control and encryption: restrict read/write to authorized roles; encrypt contact fields at rest; mask names in logs where not required.
Audit trail: log all read/write actions on customer records with staff ID, reason, and timestamp.

6. Implementation checklist and quick tasks
Schema creation in DB and CSV import template using header above.
Implement capture flows: app form with consent toggle + OTP; agent intake form with explicit consent question.
Build matching/merge job: deterministic merges by contact, weekly fuzzy match batch with manual review queue.
Personalization API: endpoint that returns Greeting text given CustomerID, channel, and context; enforce consent/usage rules serverside.
Optout API and UI: oneclick optout in app and agent dashboard; propagate immediately to messaging platform.
Logging and monitoring: dashboards for UsageCount, consent rates, merge conflicts, and optout events.
Training: agent scripts for asking name and consent, and escalation flow for disputes.
Pilot: run a 4week pilot with highvolume users, monitor errors, and refine NameVariants logic.

Examples and agent scripts
Agent script to ask permission: �May I address you by your name in messages and when we call to improve your experience? We will only use it with your permission.� If yes, record ConsentForPersonalization = true and preferred DisplayName.
Sample greeting variants: 
App (friendly): �Hi {DisplayName}, your shuttle will arrive in 7 minutes.�
SMS (concise): �{DisplayName}, your driver {DriverName} is 5 mins away.�
Phone (formal): �Good afternoon, {PreferredHonorific} {LastName}, this is Shuttle Plus.�




Google Maps integration plan � freetier usage for customer & driver tracking
A focused plan to use Google Maps Platform on the free tier for Shuttle Plus customer tracking and driver apps, covering which SKUs to use, expected pressure points, costcontrol patterns, data architecture, caching/fallbacks, monitoring, and a rollout checklist.

1. Key freetier fact to design around
Google�s updated free allocation lets you mix & match across product families; Essentials typically gives up to ~10K free calls per SKU per month, with Pro/Enterprise tiers having different allowances � use this as the planning baseline when sizing traffic Google Maps Platform.

2. Recommended SKUs and where to use them

## Bottom Line

ShuttlePlus has built an impressive operational foundation with enterprise-grade processes typically seen in much larger companies. The detailed compliance frameworks, incident protocols, and training programs suggest a team that understands the risks in transport operations.

The key question is whether this operational excellence can translate into market success in a price-sensitive market. Success will depend on:

1. Securing airport access and key corporate accounts
2. Executing technology reliably from day one
3. Building brand awareness efficiently
4. Managing capital carefully during the growth phase

The **ETB 48-55M Year 1 revenue target** is achievable with the planned fleet and utilization rates, with potential to reach **ETB 200M+ by Year 3** if corporate contracts and partner networks scale as planned.
